results.title: Danish porcelain
results.creator_credit: Gunnar Robert Hansen and Dansk Kulturfilm
results.brief_description: After tracing the history of porcelain from ancient China, shows all stages of production in the Royal Danish Porcelain Factory, and in the Bing and Grondahl Factory. Shows specimens of modern Danish ceramic art.

results.title: The Dangerous stranger [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Sid Davis and Sid Davis Productions
results.brief_description: Produced with the assistance of the Los Angeles Police Department. Designed to impress children with the need to be on guard against molesters. Dramatizes places and circumstances under which the child may encounter dangerous strangers under unsupervised conditions and indicates how to avoid potential molesters. Human interest, common sense and humour are used, but fear is scrupulously avoided. Written and photographed by Orville H. Hampton. All the perverts in this film wear sport jackets.

results.title: Dangerous noise: listen while you can
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau and Stewart Hardy Films
results.brief_description: To persuade a man that he may be incurably damaging his ears, this film adopts the philosophy that he learns best what he also understands. The physics of sound - sound waves and frequency, pitch and loudness are introduced. The film demonstrates how the ear receives the sounds and compares actual test results showing damage done to the ears by dangerous noises.

results.title: Dangerous immigrant
results.brief_description: Points out the danger of the chance introduction into Australia - in prefabricated houses and packing cases imported from overseas - of the European house borer, Hylotrupes bajulus. The life history of the pest and methods of detecting and eradicating it are treated in detail.

results.title: Danger! Radio active waste
results.creator_credit: Joan Konner, Films Incorporated and NBC News
results.brief_description: Progress is in a dead heat with destruction as the nuclear industry tries to keep ahead of its own waste, all of which is radioactive and therefore highly dangerous. The horrors of radioactive overexposure - possible genetic damage, increased incidences of cancer and leukemia, and others, are further heightened by an apparent inability of both government and industry to solve the nuclear waste disposal problem.

results.title: The Dandenong Story
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson and Cine Service Productions
results.brief_description: Dandenong, Victoria, named after an Aboriginal tribe, is a fast growing town. As the gateway to Gippsland and the Latrobe Valley, it is important for agriculture. But even more significant is the development of big industrial plants manufacturing goods such as carpets, trucks, cars and fruit cans. Such decentralization of industry is bringing prosperity and a high standard of living to Dandenong and Australia as a whole.

results.title: The Dancing class
results.brief_description: Captures the atmosphere of dedication at the Robert Pomie Ballet School. Shows a ballet class at work featuring seventeen year old Sylvia Polvolgyi. Taken in sequence the film shows the daily routine of the cleaner at work in the studio, the girls arriving, changing and going to the bar to warm up and finishing with an adagio and allegro. Camera by Tom Cowan and Nigel Buesst; music by George Dreyfus. (Gold Award, Documentary Section, 1964 Australian Film Awards)

results.title: A Dancer's world
results.creator_credit: Peter Glushanok, Nathan Kroll and WQED
results.brief_description: Martha Graham, noted choreographer and modern dancer, discusses the dancer as a creative artist. She explains the dancer’s craft as members of her company illustrate her theories in a dance choreographed by Ms Graham especially for the film. Woven into the movements of the dance are all the basic techniques required by the modern dancer.
